strings.ExperimentalPreferences-Disclaimer: The features listed here are still under development and are provided to give you an early look at some of the new functionality we're working on at GitKraken. Experimental features may not work as intended and could be changed or removed in the future. These settings are entirely optional, so if you run into any issues, you can turn them off at any time.
strings.ExperimentalPreferences-Disclaimer2: If you do experience issues, or have any other feedback, please reach out to our team at the link below to help us improve GitKraken Client.
strings.ExperimentalPreferences-GitBinaryDescrip: When this setting is enabled, GitKraken will utilize the Git executable instead of the NodeGit library for certain Git actions including fetching and committing. strings.ExperimentalPreferences-AiCommitMessageG: With this setting enabled, GitKraken will have the ability to generate commit messages from any staged changes. You can access this feature from the Command Palette (⌘+P/Ctrl+P, or the magic wand icon {0} in the toolbar), or you can click the sparkle icon {1} in the commit panel when you have staged changes.
This feature requires sending a diff of your code changes to OpenAI. Ensure your code does not contain sensitive information before generating a commit message.
Your OpenAI Key used to make the API call. GitKraken will use the gpt-3.5-turbo model for commit message generation. {0}
Click here to view or create your OpenAI API key.

strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationTitle: You've been invited to the GitKraken CLI Preview
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP1: The GitKraken CLI enhances the terminal experience for all things Git by eliminating the need to memorize Git commands and providing powerful visualizations of your repository when you need them.
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP2: You have been invited to this limited preview to test what the GitKraken team has been working on and provide feedback that will help us deliver the best CLI experience to all GitKraken users later this year.
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP3: Here is what is possible in the preview:
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP3-1: Open a GitKraken graph when changing into a directory being tracked by Git
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP3-2: Get autocomplete suggestions while writing Git commands in the terminal
strings.Cli-GainedFeatureNotificationBodyP3-3: Use the new gk program to interact with the GitKraken GUI from the terminal

strings.Cli-GitRebaseDescription: Reapply commits on top of another base tip
strings.Cli-GitRebaseOntoDescription: Starting point at which to create the new commits. If not specified, the starting point is <upstream>
strings.Cli-GitRebaseKeepBaseDescription: Set the starting point at which to create the new commits to the merge base of <upstream> <branch>.
strings.Cli-GitRebaseContinueDescription: Continue the rebasing after conflict resolution
strings.Cli-GitRebaseAbortDescription: Abort the rebase operation and reset HEAD to the original branch
strings.Cli-GitRebaseQuitDescription: Abort the rebase operation but HEAD is not reset back to the original branch
strings.Cli-GitRebaseEmptyDescription: How to handle commits that are not empty to start, but become empty after rebasing
strings.Cli-GitRebaseEmptyDropDescription: commits that become empty are dropped
strings.Cli-GitRebaseEmptyKeepDescription: commits that become empty are kept
strings.Cli-GitRebaseEmptyAskDescription: Allows you to choose whether to drop empty commits, edit files more, or just commit the empty changes.
strings.Cli-GitRebaseReapplyCherryDescription: Reapply all clean cherry-picks of any upstream commit instead of preemptively dropping them.
strings.Cli-GitRebaseNoReapplyCherryDescription: (Default) all clean cherry-picks commits will be automatically dropped.
strings.Cli-GitRebaseAllowEmptyMessageDescriptio: Allow commits with empty messages to be rebased
strings.Cli-GitRebaseEditDescription: Edit the todo list during an interactive rebase.
strings.Cli-GitRebaseShowCurrentPatchDescription: Show the current patch in an interactive rebase or when rebase is stopped because of conflicts

strings.Cli-GitRebaseXStrategyDescription: Pass the <strategy-option> through to the merge strategy.

strings.Cli-GitRebaseForkPointDescription: When is active, fork_point will be used instead of <upstream> to calculate the set of commits to rebase
strings.Cli-GitRebaseNoForkPointRebaseDescriptio: If <upstream> is given on the command line, then the default is --no-fork-point
strings.Cli-GitRebaseIgnoreWhitespaceDescription: Ignore whitespace differences when trying to reconcile differences
strings.Cli-GitRebaseWhitespaceDescription: This flag is passed to the git apply program

strings.Cli-GitAddDryRunDescription: Don't actually add the files(s), just show if they exist and/or will be ignored
strings.Cli-GitAddPatchDescription: Interactively choose hunks of patch between the index and the work tree and add them to the index
strings.Cli-GitPushTagsDescription: push tags (can't be used with --all or --mirror)
strings.Cli-GitPushAllDescription: Push all branches (i.e. refs under refs/heads/); cannot be used with other <refspec>.
strings.Cli-GitPushPruneDescription: Remove remote branches that don’t have a local counterpart. For example a remote branch tmp will be removed if a local branch with the same name doesn’t exist any more. This also respects refspecs, e.g. git push --prune remote refs/heads/*:refs/tmp/* would make sure that remote refs/tmp/foo will be removed if refs/heads/foo doesn’t exist.
strings.Cli-GitPushMirrorDescription: Instead of naming each ref to push, specifies that all refs under refs/ (which includes but is not limited to refs/heads/, refs/remotes/, and refs/tags/) be mirrored to the remote repository. Newly created local refs will be pushed to the remote end, locally updated refs will be force updated on the remote end, and deleted refs will be removed from the remote end. This is the default if the configuration option remote.<remote>.mirror is set.
strings.Cli-GitPushNDescription: Do everything except actually send the updates.
strings.Cli-GitPushDryRunDescription: Do everything except actually send the updates.
strings.Cli-GitPushPorcelainDescription: Produce machine-readable output. The output status line for each ref will be tab-separated and sent to stdout instead of stderr. The full symbolic s of the refs will be given.
strings.Cli-GitPushDeleteDescription: All listed refs are deleted from the remote repository. This is the same as prefixing all refs with a colon.
strings.Cli-GitPushFollowTagsDescription: Push all the refs that would be pushed without this option, and also push annotated tags in refs/tags that are missing from the remote but are pointing at commit-ish that are reachable from the refs being pushed. This can also be specified with configuration variable push.followTags. For more information, see push.followTags in git-config[1].
strings.Cli-GitPushSignedDescription: GPG-sign the push request to update refs on the receiving side, to allow it to be checked by the hooks and/or be logged. The push will fail if the server does not support signed pushes. If set to if-asked, sign if and only if the server supports signed pushes. The push will also fail if the actual call to gpg --sign fails.
strings.Cli-GitPushSignedTrueDescription: GPG-sign the push request to update refs on the receiving side, to allow it to be checked by the hooks and/or be logged. The push will fail if the server does not support signed pushes. The push will also fail if the actual call to gpg --sign fails.
strings.Cli-GitPushSignedFalseDescription: No GPG-sign the push request to update refs on the receiving side.
strings.Cli-GitPushSignedIfAskedDescription: Sign if and only if the server supports signed pushes.
strings.Cli-GitPushNotSignedDescription: No GPG-sign the push request to update refs on the receiving side.
strings.Cli-GitPushAtomicDescription: Use an atomic transaction on the remote side if available. Either all refs are updated, or on error, no refs are updated. If the server does not support atomic pushes the push will fail.
strings.Cli-GitPushNotAtomicDescription: Use an atomic transaction on the remote side if available. Either all refs are updated, or on error, no refs are updated. If the server does not support atomic pushes the push will fail.
strings.Cli-GitPushOptionDescription: Transmit the given option to the server, which passes them to the pre-receive as well as the post-receive hook. The given string must not contain a NUL or LF character.
strings.Cli-GitPushOption2Description: Transmit the given <option> to the server, which passes them to the pre-receive as well as the post-receive hook. The given string must not contain a NUL or LF character. When multiple --push-option=<option> are given, they are all sent to the other side in the order listed on the command line. When no --push-option=<option> is given from the command line, the values of configuration variable push.pushOption are used instead.
strings.Cli-GitPushReceivePackDescription: Path to the git-receive-pack program on the remote end. Sometimes useful when pushing to a remote repository over ssh, and you do not have the program in a directory on the default $PATH.
strings.Cli-GitPushExecDescription: Path to the git-receive-pack program on the remote end. Sometimes useful when pushing to a remote repository over ssh, and you do not have the program in a directory on the default $PATH.
strings.Cli-GitPushForceLeaseDescription: Overrides restriction to update a remote ref that is not an ancestor of the local ref
strings.Cli-GitPushNotForceLeaseDescription: Not overrides restriction to update a remote ref that is not an ancestor of the local ref
strings.Cli-GitPushForceIfIncludesDescription: Force an update only if the tip of the remote-tracking ref has been integrated locally.
strings.Cli-GitPushRepoDescription: This option is equivalent to the <repository> argument. If both are specified, the command-line argument takes precedence.
strings.Cli-GitPushSetUpstreamDescription: For every branch that is up to date or successfully pushed, add upstream (tracking) reference, used by argument-less git-pull[1] and other commands. For more information, see branch.<name>.merge in git-config[1].
strings.Cli-GitPushThinDescription: This options is passed to git-send-pack. A thin transfer significantly reduces the amount of sent data when the sender and receiver share many of the same objects in common. This is the default
strings.Cli-GitPushNotThinDescription: This options is passed to git-send-pack. A thin transfer significantly reduces the amount of sent data when the sender and receiver share many of the same objects in common.
strings.Cli-GitPushQuietDescription: Suppress all output, including the listing of updated refs, unless an error occurs. Progress is not reported to the standard error stream.
strings.Cli-GitPushProgressDescription: Progress status is reported on the standard error stream by default when it is attached to a terminal, unless -q is specified. This flag forces progress status even if the standard error stream is not directed to a terminal.
strings.Cli-GitPushSubmodulesDescription: May be used to make sure all submodule commits used by the revisions to be pushed are available on a remote-tracking branch.
strings.Cli-GitPushSubmodulesCheckDescription: Git will verify that all submodule commits that changed in the revisions to be pushed are available on at least one remote of the submodule.
strings.Cli-GitPushSubmodulesDemandDescription: All submodules that changed in the revisions to be pushed will be pushed. If it's not able to push all necessary revisions it will also be aborted and exit with non-zero status.
strings.Cli-GitPushSubmodulesOnlyDescription: All submodules will be recursively pushed while the superproject is left unpushed.
strings.Cli-GitPushSubmodulesNoDescription: Like using --no-recurse-submodules can be used to override the push.recurseSubmodules configuration variable when no submodule recursion is required.
strings.Cli-GitPushNotSubmodulesDescription: May be used to make sure all submodule commits used by the revisions to be pushed are available on a remote-tracking branch. If check is used Git will verify that all submodule commits that changed in the revisions to be pushed are available on at least one remote of the submodule. If any commits are missing the push will be aborted and exit with non-zero status. If on-demand is used all submodules that changed in the revisions to be pushed will be pushed. If on-demand was not able to push all necessary revisions it will also be aborted and exit with non-zero status. If only is used all submodules will be recursively pushed while the superproject is left unpushed. A value of no or using --no-recurse-submodules can be used to override the push.recurseSubmodules configuration variable when no submodule recursion is required.
strings.Cli-GitPushVerifyDescription: This options gives to the pre-push hook a chance to prevent the push. This is the default.
strings.Cli-GitPushNotVerifyDescription: The pre-push hook is bypassed completely.
strings.Cli-GitPullDescription: Fetch from and integrate with another repository or a local branch
strings.Cli-GitPullRebaseDescription: Fetch the remote’s copy of current branch and rebases it into the local copy
strings.Cli-GitPullCommitDescription: Perform the merge and commit the result. This option can be used to override --no-commit
strings.Cli-GitPullNoCommitDescription: Perform the merge and stop just before creating a merge commit, to give the user a chance to inspect and further tweak the merge result before committing
strings.Cli-GitPullEditDescription: Invoke an editor before committing successful mechanical merge to further edit the auto-generated merge message, so that the user can explain and justify the merge
strings.Cli-GitPullNoEditDescription: The --no-edit option can be used to accept the auto-generated message (this is generally discouraged). The --edit (or -e) option is still useful if you are giving a draft message with the -m option from the command line and want to edit it in the editor
strings.Cli-GitPullCleanupDescription: This option determines how the merge message will be cleaned up before committing. See git-commit[1] for more details. In addition, if the <mode> is given a value of scissors, scissors will be appended to MERGE_MSG before being passed on to the commit machinery in the case of a merge conflict
strings.Cli-GitPullFfDescription: When possible resolve the merge as a fast-forward (only update the branch pointer to match the merged branch; do not create a merge commit). When not possible (when the merged-in history is not a descendant of the current history), create a merge commit
strings.Cli-GitPullNoFfDescription: Create a merge commit in all cases, even when the merge could instead be resolved as a fast-forward
strings.Cli-GitPullFfOnlyDescription: Resolve the merge as a fast-forward when possible. When not possible, refuse to merge and exit with a non-zero status
strings.Cli-GitPullGPGSignDescription: GPG-sign the resulting merge commit. The keyid argument is optional and defaults to the committer identity; if specified, it must be stuck to the option without a space
strings.Cli-GitPullNoGPGSignDescription: Is useful to countermand both commit.gpgSign configuration variable, and earlier --gpg-sign
strings.Cli-GitPullLogDescription: In addition to branch names, populate the log message with one-line descriptions from at most <n> actual commits that are being merged
strings.Cli-GitPullNoLogDescription: Do not list one-line descriptions from the actual commits being merged
strings.Cli-GitPullSignOffDescription: Add a Signed-off-by trailer by the committer at the end of the commit log message. The meaning of a signoff depends on the project to which you’re committing. For example, it may certify that the committer has the rights to submit the work under the project’s license or agrees to some contributor representation, such as a Developer Certificate of Origin. (See http://developercertificate.org for the one used by the Linux kernel and Git projects.) Consult the documentation or leadership of the project to which you’re contributing to understand how the signoffs are used in that project
strings.Cli-GitPullNoSignOffDescription: Can be used to countermand an earlier --signoff option on the command line
strings.Cli-GitPullStatDescription: Show a diffstat at the end of the merge. The diffstat is also controlled by the configuration option merge.stat
strings.Cli-GitPullNoStatDescription: Do not show a diffstat at the end of the merge
strings.Cli-GitPullSquashDescription: With --squash, --commit is not allowed, and will fail. Produce the working tree and index state as if a real merge happened (except for the merge information), but do not actually make a commit, move the HEAD, or record $GIT_DIR/MERGE_HEAD (to cause the next git commit command to create a merge commit). This allows you to create a single commit on top of the current branch whose effect is the same as merging another branch (or more in case of an octopus)
strings.Cli-GitPullNoSquashDescription: perform the merge and commit the result. This option can be used to override --squash
strings.Cli-GitPullNoVerifyDescription: This option bypasses the pre-merge and commit-msg hooks
strings.Cli-GitPullStrategyDescription: Use the given merge strategy; can be supplied more than once to specify them in the order they should be tried. If there is no -s option, a built-in list of strategies is used instead (git merge-recursive when merging a single head, git merge-octopus otherwise)
strings.Cli-GitPullStrategyOptionDescription: Pass merge strategy specific option through to the merge strategy
strings.Cli-GitPullVerifySignaturesDescription: Verify that the tip commit of the side branch being merged is signed with a valid key, i.e. a key that has a valid uid: in the default trust model, this means the signing key has been signed by a trusted key. If the tip commit of the side branch is not signed with a valid key, the merge is aborted
strings.Cli-GitPullNoVerifySignaturesDescription: Do not verify that the tip commit of the side branch being merged is signed with a valid key
strings.Cli-GitPullSummaryDescription: Synonym to --stat ; this is deprecated and will be removed in the future
strings.Cli-GitPullNoSummaryDescription: Synonym to --no-stat ; this is deprecated and will be removed in the future
strings.Cli-GitPullAutostashDescription: Automatically create a temporary stash entry before the operation begins, and apply it after the operation ends. This means that you can run the operation on a dirty worktree. However, use with care: the final stash application after a successful merge might result in non-trivial conflicts
strings.Cli-GitPullNoAutostashDescription: Do not automatically create a temporary stash entry before the operation begins, and apply it after the operation ends
strings.Cli-GitPullAllowUnrelatedHistoriesDescri: By default, git merge command refuses to merge histories that do not share a common ancestor. This option can be used to override this safety when merging histories of two projects that started their lives independently. As that is a very rare occasion, no configuration variable to enable this by default exists and will not be added
strings.Cli-GitPullAppendDescription: Append ref names and object names of fetched refs to the existing contents of .git/FETCH_HEAD
strings.Cli-GitPullAtomicDescription: Use an atomic transaction to update local refs. Either all refs are updated, or on error, no refs are updated
strings.Cli-GitPullDepthDescription: Limit fetching to the specified number of commits from the tip of each remote branch history
strings.Cli-GitPullDeepenDescription: Similar to --depth, except it specifies the number of commits from the current shallow boundary instead of from the tip of each remote branch history
strings.Cli-GitPullShallowSinceDescription: Deepen or shorten the history of a shallow repository to include all reachable commits after <date>
strings.Cli-GitPullShallowExcludeDescription: Deepen or shorten the history of a shallow repository to exclude commits reachable from a specified remote branch or tag. This option can be specified multiple times
strings.Cli-GitPullUnshallowDescription: If the source repository is shallow, fetch as much as possible so that the current repository has the same history as the source repository
strings.Cli-GitPullUpdateShallowDescription: By default when fetching from a shallow repository, git fetch refuses refs that require updating .git/shallow
strings.Cli-GitPullNegotiationTipDescription: By default, Git will report, to the server, commits reachable from all local refs to find common commits in an attempt to reduce the size of the to-be-received packfile
strings.Cli-GitPullDryRunDescription: Show what would be done, without making any changes
strings.Cli-GitPullPruneDescription: Before fetching, remove any remote-tracking references that no longer exist on the remote
strings.Cli-GitPullPruneTagsDescription: Before fetching, remove any local tags that no longer exist on the remote if --prune is enabled
strings.Cli-GitPullNoTagsDescription: By default, tags that point at objects that are downloaded from the remote repository are fetched and stored locally. This option disables this automatic tag following
strings.Cli-GitPullRefMapDescription: When fetching refs listed on the command line, use the specified refspec (can be given more than once) to map the refs to remote-tracking branches, instead of the values of remote.*.fetch configuration variables for the remote repository
strings.Cli-GitPullTagsDescription: By default, tags that point at objects that are downloaded from the remote repository are fetched and stored locally. This option disables this automatic tag following
strings.Cli-GitPullRecurseSubmodulesDescription: When fetching refs listed on the command line, use the specified refspec (can be given more than once) to map the refs to remote-tracking branches, instead of the values of remote.*.fetch configuration variables for the remote repository
strings.Cli-GitPullNoRecurseSubmodulesDescriptio: Disable recursive fetching of submodules (this has the same effect as using the --recurse-submodules=no option)
strings.Cli-GitPullJobsDescription: Number of parallel children to be used for all forms of fetching
strings.Cli-GitPullSetUpstreamDescription: If the remote is fetched successfully, add upstream (tracking) reference, used by argument-less git-pull[1] and other commands
strings.Cli-GitPullUploadPackDescription: When given, and the repository to fetch from is handled by git fetch-pack, --exec=<upload-pack> is passed to the command to specify non-default path for the command run on the other end
strings.Cli-GitPullProgressDescription: Progress status is reported on the standard error stream by default when it is attached to a terminal, unless -q is specified
strings.Cli-GitPullServerOptionDescription: Transmit the given string to the server when communicating using protocol version 2. The given string must not contain a NUL or LF character
strings.Cli-GitPullShowForcedUpdatesDescription: By default, git checks if a branch is force-updated during fetch. This can be disabled through fetch.showForcedUpdates, but the --show-forced-updates option guarantees this check occurs
strings.Cli-GitPullNoShowForcedUpdatesDescriptio: By default, git checks if a branch is force-updated during fetch. Pass --no-show-forced-updates or set fetch.showForcedUpdates to false to skip this check for performance reasons
strings.Cli-GitPullIpV4Description: Use IPv4 addresses only, ignoring IPv6 addresses
strings.Cli-GitPullIpV6Description: Use IPv6 addresses only, ignoring IPv4 addresses
strings.Cli-GitDiffDescription: Show changes between commits, commit and working tree, etc
strings.Cli-GitDiffStagedDescription: Show difference between the files in the staging area and the latest version
strings.Cli-GitResetDescription: Reset current HEAD to the specified state
strings.Cli-GitResetKeepDescription: Safe: files which are different between the current HEAD and the given commit. Will abort if there are uncommitted changes
strings.Cli-GitResetSoftDescription: remove the last commit from the current branch, but the file changes will stay in your working tree
strings.Cli-GitResethardDescription: ⚠️WARNING: you will lose all uncommitted changes in addition to the changes introduced in the last commit
strings.Cli-GitResethardToHeadDescription: Reset back to any number of commits
strings.Cli-GitResetMixedDescription: keep the changes in your working tree but not on the index
strings.Cli-GitResetMixedToHeadDescription: Reset back any number of commits
strings.Cli-GitResetMergeDescription: Resets the index and updates the files in the working tree that are different between 'commit' and HEAD
strings.Cli-GitLogOnelineDescription: Show each commit as a single line
strings.Cli-GitRemoteSetHeadDescription: Sets or deletes the default branch
strings.Cli-GitRemoteGetUrlDescription: Retrieves the URLs for a remote
strings.Cli-GitRemoteSetUrlDescription: Changes the URLs for the remote
strings.Cli-GitRemoteShowDescription: Gives some information about the remote [name]
strings.Cli-GitRemotePruneDescription: Equivalent to git fetch --prune [name], except that no new references will be fetched
strings.Cli-GitRemotePruneDryRunDescription: Do not delete anything, but show what would be deleted
strings.Cli-GitRemoteUpdateDescription: Fetch updates for remotes or remote groups in the repository as defined by remotes.<group> or remotes<name>
strings.Cli-GitRemoteFetchDescription: Fetch after remote info is added
strings.Cli-GitRemoteVerboseDescription: Show more information about the refspecs processed
strings.Cli-GitFetchDescription: Download objects and refs from another repository
strings.Cli-GitFetchAppendDescription: Append ref names and object names of fetched refs to the existing contents of .git/FETCH_HEAD
strings.Cli-GitFetchAtomicDescription: Use an atomic transaction to update local refs. Either all refs are updated, or on error, no refs are updated.
strings.Cli-GitFetchDepthDescription: Limit fetching to the specified number of commits from the tip of each remote branch history
strings.Cli-GitFetchDeepenDescription: Similar to --depth, except it specifies the number of commits from the current shallow boundary instead of from the tip of each remote branch history
strings.Cli-GitFetcShallowSinceDescription: Deepen or shorten the history of a shallow repository to include all reachable commits after <date>
strings.Cli-GitFetchShallowExcludeDescription: Deepen or shorten the history of a shallow repository to exclude commits reachable from a specified remote branch or tag. This option can be specified multiple times
strings.Cli-GitFetchUnshallowDescription: If the source repository is shallow, fetch as much as possible so that the current repository has the same history as the source repository
strings.Cli-GitFetchUpdateShallowDescription: By default when fetching from a shallow repository, git fetch refuses refs that require updating .git/shallow
strings.Cli-GitFetchNegotiationDescription: By default, Git will report, to the server, commits reachable from all local refs to find common commits in an attempt to reduce the size of the to-be-received packfile
strings.Cli-GitFetchDryRunDescription: Show what would be done, without making any changes.
strings.Cli-GitFetchWriteHeadDescription: Write the list of remote refs fetched in the FETCH_HEAD file directly under $GIT_DIR. This is the default
strings.Cli-GitFetchNotWriteHeadDescription: Tells Git not to write the file
strings.Cli-GitFetchMultipleDescription: Allow several <repository> and <group> arguments to be specified. No <refspec>s may be specified.
strings.Cli-GitFetchMaintenanceDescription: Run git maintenance run --auto at the end to perform automatic repository maintenance if
strings.Cli-GitFetchNoMaintenanceDescription: Don't run git maintenance run --auto at the end to perform automatic repository maintenance
strings.Cli-GitFetchWriteGraphDescription: Write a commit-graph after fetching. This overrides the config setting fetch.writeCommitGraph
strings.Cli-GitFetchNotWriteGraphDescription: Don't write a commit-graph after fetching. This overrides the config setting fetch.writeCommitGraph
strings.Cli-GitFetchPruneDescription: Before fetching, remove any remote-tracking references that no longer exist on the remote
strings.Cli-GitFetchPruneTagsDescription: Before fetching, remove any local tags that no longer exist on the remote if --prune is enabled
strings.Cli-GitFetchNotTagsDescription: By default, tags that point at objects that are downloaded from the remote repository are fetched and stored locally. This option disables this automatic tag following
strings.Cli-GitFetchRefmapDescription: When fetching refs listed on the command line, use the specified refspec (can be given more than once) to map the refs to remote-tracking branches, instead of the values of remote.*.fetch configuration variables for the remote repository
strings.Cli-GitFetchTagsDescription: By default, tags that point at objects that are downloaded from the remote repository are fetched and stored locally. This option disables this automatic tag following
strings.Cli-GitFetchJobsDescription: Number of parallel children to be used for all forms of fetching.
strings.Cli-GitFetchNoSubmodulesDescription: Disable recursive fetching of submodules (this has the same effect as using the --recurse-submodules=no option).
strings.Cli-GitFetchSetUpstreamDescription: If the remote is fetched successfully, add upstream (tracking) reference, used by argument-less git-pull1 and other commands.
strings.Cli-GitFetchSubmodulesDescription: Prepend <path> to paths printed in informative messages such as 'Fetching submodule foo'. This option is used internally when recursing over submodules.
strings.Cli-GitFetchUpdateHeadDescription: By default git fetch refuses to update the head which corresponds to the current branch. This flag disables the check. This is purely for the internal use for git pull to communicate with git fetch, and unless you are implementing your own Porcelain you are not supposed to use it.
strings.Cli-GitFetchUploadPackDescription: When given, and the repository to fetch from is handled by git fetch-pack, --exec=<upload-pack> is passed to the command to specify non-default path for the command run on the other end.
strings.Cli-GitFetchQuietDescription: Pass --quiet to git-fetch-pack and silence any other internally used git commands. Progress is not reported to the standard error stream.
strings.Cli-GitFetchprogressDescription: Progress status is reported on the standard error stream by default when it is attached to a terminal, unless -q is specified.
strings.Cli-GitFetchOptionDescription: Transmit the given string to the server when communicating using protocol version 2. The given string must not contain a NUL or LF character.
strings.Cli-GitFetchShowForcedDescription: By default, git checks if a branch is force-updated during fetch. This can be disabled through fetch.showForcedUpdates, but the --show-forced-updates option guarantees this check occurs
strings.Cli-GitFetchNotShowForcedDescription: By default, git checks if a branch is force-updated during fetch. Pass --no-show-forced-updates or set fetch.showForcedUpdates to false to skip this check for performance reasons.
strings.Cli-GitIPV4Description: Use IPv4 addresses only, ignoring IPv6 addresses.
strings.Cli-GitIPV6Description: Use IPv6 addresses only, ignoring IPv4 addresses.
strings.Cli-GitFetchStdinDescription: Use binary search to find the commit that introduced a bug
strings.Cli-GitStashDescription: Stash the changes in a dirty working directory away
strings.Cli-GitStashPushDescription: Save your local modifications to a new stash entry and roll them back to HEAD.
strings.Cli-GitStashPushPatchDescription: Interactively select hunks from the diff between HEAD and the working tree to be stashed.
strings.Cli-GitStashPushKeepIndexDescription: All changed already added to the index are left intact.
strings.Cli-GitStashPushIncludeDescription: All untracked files are also stashed and then cleaned up.
strings.Cli-GitStashPushAllDescription: All ignored and untracked files are also stashed.
strings.Cli-GitStashPushMessageDescription: Use the given <msg> as the stash message.
strings.Cli-GitStashPathspecFromFileDescription: Pathspec is passed in <file> instead of commandline args
strings.Cli-GitStashHyphenDescription: Separates pathsec from options for disambiguation purposes.
strings.Cli-GitStashShowDescription: Show the changes recorded in the stash entry as a diff.
strings.Cli-GitStashSaveDescription: Stash the changes in a dirty working directory away
strings.Cli-GitStashSavePatchDescription: Interactively select hunks from the diff between HEAD and the working tree to be stashed.
strings.Cli-GitStashSaveIndexDescription: All changed already added to the index are left intact.
strings.Cli-GitStashSaveIncludeUntrackedDescript: All untracked files are also stashed and then cleaned up.
strings.Cli-GitStashSaveAllDescription: All ignored and untracked files are also stashed.
strings.Cli-GitQuietOptionDescription: Quiet, suppress feedback messages from command line.
strings.Cli-GitStashPopDescription: Restores the most recently stashed files
strings.Cli-GitStashPopIndexDescription: Tries to reinstate not only the working tree's changes, but also the index's ones.
strings.Cli-GitStashDropDescription: Discards the most recently stashed changeset
strings.Cli-GitStashApplyDescription: Like pop, but do not remove the state from the stash list.
strings.Cli-GitStashApplyIndexDescription: Tries to reinstate not only the working tree's changes, but also the index's ones.
strings.Cli-GitStashBranchDescription: Creates and checks out a new branch named
strings.Cli-GitStashCreateDescription: Creates a stash with the message <msg>
strings.Cli-GitStashStoreDescription: Store a given stash in the stash ref., updating the staft reflog.
strings.Cli-GitStashStoreMessageDescription: Use the given <msg> as the stash message.
strings.Cli-GitReflogDescription: Show history of events with hashes
strings.Cli-GitCloneDescription: Clone a repository into a new directory
strings.Cli-GitInitDescription: Create an empty Git repository or reinitialize an existing one
strings.Cli-GitMoveDescription: Move or rename a file, a directory, or a symlink
strings.Cli-GitRemoveDescription: Remove files from the working tree and from the index
strings.Cli-GitRemoveHyphenDescription: used to separate command-line options from the list of files
strings.Cli-GitBranchAllDescription: list both remote-tracking and local branches
strings.Cli-GitBranchRenameDescription: move/rename current branch and its reflog
strings.Cli-GitBranchMoveDescription: move/rename current branch, even if target exists
strings.Cli-GitBranchcDescription: copy a branch and its reflog
strings.Cli-GitBranchCDescription: copy a branch, even if target exists
strings.Cli-GitBranchEditDescription: edit the description for the branch
strings.Cli-GitBranchMergedDescription: print only branches that are merged
strings.Cli-GitBranchNotMergedDescription: print only branches that are not merged
strings.Cli-GitBranchPointsAtDescription: print only branches of the object
strings.Cli-GitBranchIgnoreDescription: sorting and filtering are case insensitive
strings.Cli-GitBranchFormatDescription: format to use for the output
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutDescription: Switch branches or restore working tree files
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutbDescription: create and checkout a new branch
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutTrackDescription: set upstream info for new branch
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutOursDescription: checkout our version for unmerged files
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutTheirsDescription: checkout their version for unmerged files
strings.Cli-GitCheckoutMergeDescription: perform a 3-way merge with the new branch
strings.Cli-GitMergeDescription: Join two or more development histories together
strings.Cli-GitMergeCommitDescription: Perform the merge and commit the result
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoCommitDescription: Perform the merge and stop just before creating a merge commit
strings.Cli-GitMergeEditDescription: Invoke an editor before committing successful mechanical merge to further edit the auto-generated merge message
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoEditDescription: Used to accept the auto-generated message
strings.Cli-GitMergeCleanupDescription: This option determines how the merge message will be cleaned up before committing
strings.Cli-GitMergeMessageDescription: Set the commit message to be used for the merge commit (in case one is created)
strings.Cli-GitMergeFastForwardDescription: Fast-forward (Default): when possible resolve the merge as a fast-forward (only update the branch pointer to match the merged branch; do not create a merge commit). When not possible, create a merge commit
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoFastForwardDescription: No-fast-forward: create a merge commit in all cases, even when the merge could instead be resolved as a fast-forward
strings.Cli-GitMergeFastForwardOnlyDescription: Fast-forward-only: Resolve the merge as a fast-forward when possible. When not possible, refuse to merge and exit with a non-zero status
strings.Cli-GitMergeAbortDescription: Abort the current conflict resolution process, and try to reconstruct the pre-merge state. If an autostash entry is present, apply it to the worktree
strings.Cli-GitMergeQuitDescription: Forget about the current merge in progress. Leave the index and the working tree as-is. If MERGE_AUTOSTASH is present, the stash entry will be saved to the stash list
strings.Cli-GitMergeContinueDescription: After a git merge stops due to conflicts you can conclude the merge by running git merge --continue after resolving conflicts
strings.Cli-GitMergeGpgSignDescription: GPG-sign the resulting merge commit, 'Keyid' is optional
strings.Cli-GitMergeGpgSignKeyDescription: GPG-sign the resulting merge commit, '=Keyid' is optional
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoGpgSignDescription: Do not GPG-sign the resulting merge commit
strings.Cli-GitMergeLogDescription: In addition to branch names, populate the log message with one-line descriptions from at most <n> actual commits that are being merged
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoLogDescription: Do not list one-line descriptions from the actual commits being merged
strings.Cli-GitMergeSignOffDescription: Add a Signed-off-by trailer by the committer at the end of the commit log message
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoSignOffDescription: Can be used to countermand an earlier --signoff option on the command line
strings.Cli-GitMergeStatDescription: Show a diffstat at the end of the merge
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoStat: Do not show a diffstat at the end of the merge
strings.Cli-GitMergeVerifySignaturesDescription: Verify that the tip commit of the side branch being merged is signed with a valid key, if not the merge is aborted
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoVerifySignaturesDescriptio: Do not verify signature if it was previously configured to do so
strings.Cli-GitMergeAutostashDescription: Automatically create a temporary stash entry before the operation begins, and apply it after the operation ends
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoAutostashDescription: Do not create a temporary stash entry
strings.Cli-GitMergeAllowUnrelatedHistoriesDescr: Allow to merge histories that do not share a common ancestor
strings.Cli-GitMergeFileDescription: Merge commit message to be use read by file given
strings.Cli-GitMergeReReReDescription: Allow the rerere mechanism to update the index with the result of auto-conflict resolution if possible
strings.Cli-GitMergeNoReReReDescription: Do not let the rerere mechanism to update the index
strings.Cli-GitMergeOverWriteIgnoreDescription: Silently overwrite ignored files from the merge result. default behavior
strings.Cli-GitTagDescription: Create, list, delete or verify a tag object signed with GPG
strings.Cli-GitTagNDescription: Print <n> lines of each tag message
strings.Cli-GitGcDescription: Cleanup unnecessary files and optimize the local repository
strings.Cli-GitGcPruneDescription: Prune loose objects older than given date. --prune is on by default
strings.Cli-GitGcPruneNowDescription: Prunes loose objects regardless of their age and increases the risk of corruption if another process is writing to the repository concurrently
strings.Cli-GitGcNoPruneDescription: Do not prune any loose objects.
strings.Cli-GitGcForceDescription: Force git gc to run even if there may be another git gc instance running on this repository.
strings.Cli-GitGcKeepLargestPackDescription: Repack all other packs except the largest pack
strings.Cli-GitFlowShowCommandsDescription: Show git commands while executing them
strings.Cli-GitFlowFetchDescription: Fetch from origin before performing operation

strings.InitialWorkspacesExperience-Slide01Messa: Create a Workspace to easily access the repos you work with the most. See the status of all repos at a glance, including which branches are checked out and what work you have in progress. Perform actions across all repos to keep them up to date.
strings.InitialWorkspacesExperience-Slide02Messa: Cloud Workspaces are enhanced with pull request & issue data from popular services like GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, Jira and Trello. They help you focus on your most important tasks so work gets started and merged faster.
strings.InitialWorkspacesExperience-Slide03Messa: Share Cloud Workspaces with your teams to keep everyone aligned on the same repositories and see pull requests & issues for all team members in a separate Team View.
strings.InitialWorkspacesExperience-Slide04Messa: Shared Workspaces reduce the time it takes to onboard new members of your team by allowing them to quickly clone multiple repositories at once. This is also helpful when getting a new machine up and running!
strings.InitialWorkspacesExperience-Slide05Messa: GitKraken Insights increase the velocity of your projects by helping you and your team understand how many pull requests are being opened and merged over time for all of your repositories.

strings.WorkspacePullRequestMetrics-AverageCycle: The average time it takes for a pull request to be merged for the selected timeframe. It measures the total time a pull request takes from the 1st commit until it is merged. A high Cycle Time can indicate too much complexity in your team's pull requests causing bottlenecks in your ability to stay on pace with your workload. Average Cycle Time is also known as "Lead Time for Changes."
strings.WorkspacePullRequestMetrics-AverageThrou: The average number of pull requests merged for the selected timeframe. It refers to the cadence of how often code changes are being merged/deployed. Generally, smaller and much more frequent changes have been correlated with improved code quality and developer health. Each team is different however, and reasonable goals should be decided on for your team's unique situation. Average Throughput is also known as "Deployment Frequency."
strings.WorkspacePullRequestMetrics-MergedToolti: The total number of pull requests merged for the selected timeframe.
strings.WorkspacePullRequestMetrics-MergeRateToo: The percentage of merged pull requests compared to open pull requests for the selected timeframe. If there are more pull requests being created than merged for too long, it can be a sign of technical debt increasing and developer overload.
strings.WorkspacePullRequestMetrics-OpenedToolti: The total number of pull requests opened for the selected timeframe.
